title: Hollandaise Sauce for Two: A Classic and Easy Recipe
directions: Choose a small saucepan and a metal or heat-proof glass bowl that fits securely in the top of the pan.Put 1/2-1 inch of water into the saucepan (just enough so the water level doesn't quite touch the bottom of the bowl when it's set in the pan.)Set the pan over high heat.Once it boils, turn the heat down to keep the water at a bare simmer.
Put 1/2-1 inch of water into the saucepan (just enough so the water level doesn't quite touch the bottom of the bowl when it's set in the pan.)
Set the pan over high heat.
Once it boils, turn the heat down to keep the water at a bare simmer.

In the bowl, whisk the egg yolks, 1 1/2 teaspoons of lemon juice, salt, and pepper until the mixture is uniformly yellow and slightly thickened.Set the bowl in the pan and whisk slowly but constantly until the mixture starts to thicken.Be sure to whisk throughout all parts of the bowl.If steam starts to leak from underneath the bowl, turn the heat down a little.
Set the bowl in the pan and whisk slowly but constantly until the mixture starts to thicken.
Be sure to whisk throughout all parts of the bowl.
If steam starts to leak from underneath the bowl, turn the heat down a little.

Add one piece of butter. Continue whisking until the butter is incorporated, then add another piece of butter. Repeat until all the butter is incorporated.The sauce should be thick, smooth, and glossy.
The sauce should be thick, smooth, and glossy.
Adjust the seasoning, adding more lemon juice if desired.

Remove the pan from the heat.It will keep over the hot water for a half-hour or more, provided you whisk it occasionally.Another option is to pour the sauce into a thermos or air pot until you're ready to serve.
